Board Games & Video Games.name: Pixel & Parchment: A Board & Video Game Gauntlet
Board Games & Video Games.description: Test your knowledge across the realms of tabletop strategy and digital adventures! This quiz blends classic board game mechanics with iconic video game lore, challenging you to identify key concepts, characters, and innovations. Are you a seasoned strategist or a casual gamer? Let's find out!

questions.text: In the board game 'Terraforming Mars', what is the primary goal of players?
questions.hint: Think about what the game's title suggests  what are you trying to do to the planet?
questions.option1: Establish a thriving alien civilization.
questions.option2: Increase the oxygen level and temperature of Mars to make it habitable.
questions.option3: Mine valuable resources and build a Martian empire.
questions.option4: Discover ancient Martian artifacts and unlock their power.

questions.text: Which of these is a defining characteristic of the 'Roguelike' video game genre?
questions.hint: Consider the elements that make a game 'difficult' and 'replayable'.
questions.option1: A linear storyline with multiple endings.
questions.option2: Open-world exploration with a focus on crafting.
questions.option4: Real-time combat with a large party of characters.

questions.text: In the board game 'Ticket to Ride', what is the purpose of Destination Tickets?
questions.hint: These cards provide a specific objective for players to achieve.
questions.option1: To earn bonus points for collecting different colored trains.
questions.option2: To connect specific cities on the game board.
questions.option3: To block other players from claiming routes.
questions.option4: To gain extra resources during the game.

questions.text: What is the core mechanic that defines the 'Metroidvania' video game subgenre?
questions.hint: Think about how exploration and ability acquisition are intertwined.
questions.option1: A focus on turn-based combat and strategic planning.
questions.option2: Non-linear exploration with interconnected areas and ability-gated progression.
questions.option3: A procedurally generated world with permadeath.
questions.option4: A narrative-driven experience with multiple branching storylines.

questions.text: In the board game 'Catan' (formerly 'Settlers of Catan'), what is the significance of the robber?
questions.hint: It's a piece that can disrupt other players' strategies.
questions.option1: It provides bonus resources to the player who controls it.
questions.option2: It allows players to build roads for free.
questions.option3: It blocks resource production from a hex and allows the player to steal a card.
questions.option4: It protects settlements from attacks by other players.

questions.text: Which of these best describes the 'JRPG' (Japanese Role-Playing Game) genre?
questions.hint: Consider the common themes and gameplay elements found in games like Final Fantasy and Dragon Quest.
questions.option1: A fast-paced, first-person shooter with a focus on reflexes.
questions.option2: A real-time strategy game with a focus on base building and resource management.
questions.option3: A turn-based combat system, a strong narrative focus, and character progression.
questions.option4: A sandbox game with a focus on player freedom and emergent gameplay.

questions.text: In the board game 'Pandemic', what is the primary objective for the players?
questions.hint: The name itself gives a strong clue about the game's goal.
questions.option1: To build the most advanced research facilities.
questions.option2: To eradicate all diseases threatening humanity.
questions.option3: To accumulate the most wealth and influence.
questions.option4: To discover the origin of the pandemic.

questions.text: What is a key characteristic of the 'Souls-like' video game genre?
questions.hint: Think about the difficulty and the player's response to failure.
questions.option1: A forgiving difficulty curve and frequent checkpoints.
questions.option2: A focus on puzzle-solving and exploration.
questions.option3: High difficulty, deliberate combat, and a sense of accomplishment through overcoming challenges.
questions.option4: A focus on narrative storytelling and character development.

questions.text: In the board game '7 Wonders', what is the purpose of the 'Age' cards?
questions.hint: They dictate the order in which players take actions and build structures.
questions.option1: To provide players with bonus resources.
questions.option2: To determine the order of play in each round.
questions.option3: To allow players to sabotage their opponents' progress.
questions.option4: To provide players with special abilities and actions.

questions.text: What is a defining feature of the 'Auto Battler' video game genre?
questions.hint: Consider how units are deployed and how battles are resolved.
questions.option1: Players directly control a single character in a 3D environment.
questions.option2: Players strategically deploy units that automatically battle each other.
questions.option3: Players build and manage a virtual city or kingdom.
questions.option4: Players solve puzzles and explore dungeons in a top-down perspective.

questions.text: What is a key difference between 'Save States' in video games and the concept of 'Luck' in many board games?
questions.hint: Consider the level of control players have over their progress.

questions.option2: Luck allows for strategic planning, while Save States limit player agency.
questions.option3: Save States are only available in single-player games, while luck is essential in multiplayer games.
questions.option4: Luck is a modern invention, while Save States have been around since the earliest video games.
